argumentText:
Let $(\Omega,\mathcal{F},(\mathcal{F}_t)_{t\in\mathbb{T}},\mathbb{P})$
be a filtered probability space with countable index set $\mathbb{T}$.
If $(X_t)_{t\in\mathbb{T}}$ is a submartingale, we show that
$$\label{eq:1}
\mathbb{P}\left(\sup_{s\le t}X_s\ge K\right)\le K^{-1}\mathbb{E}[(X_t)_+]$$
and if $X$ is a martingale or nonnegative submartingale then,
$$\begin{gathered}
\label{eq:2}\mathbb{P}(X^*_t\ge K)\le K^{-1}\mathbb{E}[|X_t|],\\
\label{eq:3}\Vert X^*_t\Vert_p\le \frac{p}{p-1}\Vert X_t\Vert_p. \end{gathered}$$
for every $K>0$ and $p>1$.

First, let us consider the case where $\mathbb{T}$ is finite. The first
time at which $X_t\ge K$,
$$\tau=\inf\left\{t\in\mathbb{T}:X_t\ge K\right\}$$ is a stopping time
(as hitting times are stopping times). By Doob’s optional sampling
theorem for submartingales
$X_{\tau\wedge t}\le\mathbb{E}[X_t\mid\mathcal{F}_{\tau\wedge t}]$ and
therefore, $$K\mathbb{P}(\tau\le t)
\le\mathbb{E}[1_{\{\tau\le t\}}X_{\tau\wedge t}]
\le\mathbb{E}[1_{\{\tau\le t\}}X_{t}]$$ However, $\tau\le t$ if and only
if $\sup_{s\le t}X_s\ge K$ giving, $$\label{eq:4}
\mathbb{P}\left(\sup_{s\le t}X_s\ge K\right)\le K^{-1}\mathbb{E}[1_{\{\sup_{s\le t}X_s\ge K\}}X_t],$$
where the supremum is understood to be over $s\in\mathbb{T}$. Now
suppose that $\mathbb{T}$ is countable. Then choose finite subsets
$\mathbb{T}_n\subseteq\mathbb{T}$ which increase to $\mathbb{T}$ as $n$
goes to infinity. Replacing $\mathbb{T}$ by $\mathbb{T}_n$ in inequality
(\[eq:4\]) and using the monotone convergence theorem to take the limit
$n\rightarrow\infty$ extends (\[eq:4\]) to arbitrary uncountable index
sets. Then, inequality (\[eq:1\]) follows immediately from (\[eq:4\]).

Now, suppose that $X$ is a martingale. Jensen’s inequality gives
$$\mathbb{E}[|X_t|\mid\mathcal{F}_s]\ge \left|\mathbb{E}[X_t\mid\mathcal{F}_s]\right|=|X_s|$$
for any $s<t$, so $|X|$ is a nonnegative submartingale. Therefore, it is
enough to prove inequalities (\[eq:2\]) and (\[eq:3\]) for $X$ a
nonnegative submartingale, and the martingale case follows by replacing
$X$ by $|X|$.

So, we take $X$ to be a nonnegative submartingale in the following. In
this case, (\[eq:2\]) just reduces to (\[eq:1\]) and it only remains to
prove inequality (\[eq:3\]).

For $p>1$, multiply (\[eq:4\]) by $K^{p-1}$ and integrate up to some
limit $L>0$, $$\label{eq:5}
\int_0^LK^{p-1}\mathbb{P}(X^*_t\ge K)\,dK\le \int_0^LK^{p-2}\mathbb{E}[1_{\{X^*_t\ge K\}}X_t]\,dK.$$
The left hand side of this inequality can be computed by commuting the
order of integration with respect to $\mathbb{P}$ and $dK$ (Fubini’s
theorem), $$\begin{split}
\int_0^L K^{p-1}\mathbb{P}(X^*_t\ge K)\,dK
&=\mathbb{E}\left[\int_0^L K^{p-1}1_{\{X^*_t\ge K\}}\,dK\right]\\
&=\frac{1}{p}\mathbb{E}[(L\wedge X^*)^p].
\end{split}$$ The right hand side of (\[eq:5\]) can be computed
similarly, $$\begin{split}
\int_0^LK^{p-2}\mathbb{E}[1_{\{X^*_t\ge K\}}X_t]\,dK
&=\mathbb{E}\left[X_t\int_0^LK^{p-2}1_{\{X^*_t\ge K\}}\,dK\right]\\
&=\frac{1}{p-1}\mathbb{E}[X_t(L\wedge X^*_t)^{p-1}].
\end{split}$$ Putting these back into (\[eq:5\]), $$\label{eq:6}
\Vert L\wedge X^*_t\Vert_p^p\le\frac{p}{p-1}\mathbb{E}[X_t(L\wedge X^*_t)^{p-1}].$$
Now let $q=p/(p-1)$, so that $p,q$ are and the Hölder inequality gives
$$\mathbb{E}[X_t(L\wedge X^*_t)^{p-1}]
\le\Vert X_t\Vert_p \Vert (L\wedge X^*_t)^{p-1}\Vert_q
=\Vert X_t\Vert_p \Vert L\wedge X^*_t\Vert_p^{p-1}.$$ Substituting into
(\[eq:6\]), the finite term $\Vert L\wedge X^*_t\Vert_p^{p-1}$ cancels
to get $$\Vert L\wedge X^*_t \Vert_p\le \frac{p}{p-1}\Vert X_t\Vert_p,$$
and the result follows by letting $L$ increase to infinity.
